Award.AwardTitle: Extremal metrics, the Calabi flow and related PDEs
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the study of the extremal metrics in Kaehler geometry, the Calabi flow and related PDEs, such as the complex Monge-Ampere equation and an operator recently suggested by S. Donaldson. The stability conjecture in Kaehler geometry relates the existence of the extremal metrics to the stability of the underlying complex projective variety. The stability conjecture and related problems are fundamental problems in Kaehler geometry, which has tight relation with the partial differential equations, complex analysis and algebraic geometry. The precise understanding of the Calabi flow will lead to solving such a conjecture. Inspired by Perelman's success in Hamilton's problem to solve geometrization conjecture by Ricci flow, the PI proposes to study the Calabi flow to attack the existence of extremal metrics. The key issue for the Calabi flow is the long time existence, the asymptotic behavior and related problems. Based on the previous work of the PI and his collaborators, he plans to further study the Calabi flow on Kaehler surfaces, in particular on Del Pezzo surfaces and toric surfaces. The PI also plans to study the regularity problem of related PDEs, such as the complex Monge-Ampere equation, which is a fundamental equation in Kaehler geometry and is also closely related to the extremal metrics and the Calabi flow. In particular, the PI plans to study whether some regularity result, which has been proved for the real Monge-Ampere equation, holds or not for the complex Monge-Ampere equation. The study of S. Donaldson's operator will give new insight on this. Donaldson's operator can be viewed as an operator with some nature of both the real and complex Monge-Ampere operators.

Problems in the proposal arise naturally from our attempts to understand geometric partial dierential equations from geometry and physics, which have tight relation with many other fields such as algebraic geometry, complex analysis and mathematical physics. One of the key features of these problems is how the global structure of a space influences the local, analytic properties of the solutions of such equations. Understanding this general principle will have broad impact in physics and other fields of science in general. The proposed research will have immediate beneficial effect on students in PI's home university.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The study of extremal Kahler metrics, which include Kahler metrics with constant scalar curvature and the very famous Kahler-Einstein metrics as special cases, has been very active in several decades. 

In the project entitled "Extremal metrics, the Calabi flow and related PDEs", we propse to study the Calabi flow, complex Monge-Ampere equations and other related partial differenital equations to understand the existence of extremal metrics in a fixed Kahler class. The Calabi flow is defined by E. Calabi in 1980s in his first to define and study extremal metrics. And it is  a geometric flow to approach the existence problem of extremal metrics. The complex Monge-Ampere equation is one of the central topics in Kahler geometry and has been one of the most important nonlinear elliptic PDEs studied in geometric analysis and PDE theory. 

I have obtained significant progress in all  problems propsed in this project, and have published about 15 papers  in respectful math journals (some with collaborators).

In short, most of my results have made important contribution to the related subjects in geometric analysis; and many of them have been followed and used extensively by other authors and researchers in these subjects. For example, my results in the Calabi flow have stimulated considerate interest in this subject and have obtained extensive attention in community. Before our series work (joint with X.X. Chen), there is virtually no result in complex dimension 2 or higher. Our first paper gives a start on this subject and after that the Calabi flow has been studied by many authors. Our results are also used crucially by others to study the Calabi flow and related problems. 

Next I will briefly summarize my results and findings.

1. I have made important progress on the study of extremal metrics and the Calabi flow. In a series of work with X.X. Chen, we have established the maximal regularity for the short time solution of the Calabi flow, and proved that if the Ricci curvature is bounded then the Calabi flow exists for all time. On Kahler surfaces, we have obtained nice description on the formation of singularities. On toric del Pezzo surfaces, we have established long time existence and convergence to extremal metrics with mild assumption on initial metric.  We also study the shortime existence with very rough initial metrics. I showed the flow can start and become smooth instantly with only Holder continuous metrics. Recently we are working on even weaker conditions such as continuous initial metrics.

2.  I have made significant progress on the complex Monge-Ampere equations, in both compact Kahler manifolds and manifolds with boundary. The complex Monge-Ampere equation plays a key role in Kahler geometry. The very famous Calabi conjecture, solved by Yau in late 1970s,  is to prove the existence of a unique smooth solution of the complex Monge-Ampere equation on compact Kahler manifolds. Since then, the study of the complex Monge-Ampere equation has been extensive and there are lots of progress and publications in literature regarding this problem. I have obtained several important advances in these directions.

The first one is to improve Yau's regularity result on the complex Monge-Ampere equation on compact Kahler manifolds in an optimal way. Both our results and our method are important, and have been used in other cases such as complex Monge-Ampere equation on Hermitian manifolds. 

The second one is  the geodesic equation of the space of Kahler potentials.
